messages.content:
Can you help me translate this david whyte poem and change it slightly to make sure that people with english as a second language can understand?
Everything is Waiting for You
Written and read by David Whyte


Listen
After Derek Mahon

Your great mistake is to act the drama
as if you were alone. As if life
were a progressive and cunning crime
with no witness to the tiny hidden
transgressions. To feel abandoned is to deny
the intimacy of your surroundings. Surely,
even you, at times, have felt the grand array;
the swelling presence, and the chorus, crowding
out your solo voice. You must note
the way the soap dish enables you,
or the window latch grants you freedom.
Alertness is the hidden discipline of familiarity.
The stairs are your mentor of things
to come, the doors have always been there
to frighten you and invite you,
and the tiny speaker in the phone
is your dream-ladder to divinity.

Put down the weight of your aloneness and ease into the
conversation. The kettle is singing
even as it pours you a drink, the cooking pots
have left their arrogant aloofness and
seen the good in you at last. All the birds
and creatures of the world are unutterably
themselves. Everything is waiting for you.

Here's an adapted version of the poem that simplifies some of the language and concepts to make it easier to understand for someone who speaks English as a second language:

Listen
Inspired by Derek Mahon

You're wrong if you live your life
thinking you're alone. As if life
was a complex and clever secret wrongdoing,
with no one seeing your small hidden
mistakes. To feel alone is to forget
how close your surroundings are. Surely,
even you, sometimes, have felt the immense display;
the strong presence, and the choir, overpowering
your own voice. You should notice
how the soap dish helps you,
or the window lock gives you freedom.
Being aware is the secret skill of knowing the familiar.
The stairs are your guide to future
events, the doors have always been there
to scare you and welcome you,
and the small speaker in the phone
is your dream path to something divine.

Let go of your feeling of loneliness and join the
conversation. The kettle is making sound
even as it pours you a drink, the cooking pots
have abandoned their proud solitude and
recognized your goodness at last. All the birds
and animals of the world are incredibly
themselves. Everything is waiting for you.
can you adapt it further and make it sound like david whyte wrote it originally

Certainly, I understand that you're looking for a simplified version that maintains the original's poetic style and tone. Here's another adaptation:

Listen
Inspired by Derek Mahon

Your great misstep is to live your tale
as if you were alone. As if existence
was an unfolding, sly mystery,
with no observer to your secret, small
missteps. To feel forsaken is to dismiss
the closeness of your world. Undoubtedly,
even you, at times, have sensed the grand spectacle;
the rich presence, the chorus, eclipsing
your lone voice. You must recognize
how the soap dish assists you,
or the window latch offers you liberty.
Attentiveness is the unseen practice of the well-known.
The stairs are your guide to what's
to come, the doors have always existed
to unsettle you and beckon you,
and the tiny speaker within the phone
is your dream-path to the divine.

Release the burden of your solitude and transition into the
dialogue. The kettle is serenading
even as it prepares your drink, the cooking pots
have left their haughty detachment and
acknowledged your worth at last. All the birds
and beings of this world are completely
themselves. Everything awaits you.
